item.title: The Year Hollywood Finally Confronted Our Political Moment
item.description: In movies like “Eddington,” “Sinners,” “Wake Up Dead Man” and others, filmmakers have at last wrapped their heads around how to explain this period.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson
item.category: Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery (Movie)

item.title: ‘Ella McCay’ Review: Right Girl, Wrong Time
item.description: James L. Brooks returns with a lieutenant governor comedy that might leave you more confused than amused.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: ‘Resurrection’ Review: Bi Gan’s Voyage Into Cinema
item.description: The Chinese director Bi Gan, who has become a lauded fixture on the festival circuit, conjures a boundary-pushing tale that evokes moviemaking itself.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: Watch an Ensemble Scene From ‘Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery’
item.description: The writer and director Rian Johnson narrates a sequence from his film.
item.dc:creator: Mekado Murphy
item.category: Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery (Movie)

item.title: 6 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
item.description: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: ‘Dust Bunny’ Review: A World of Wonders, Familiar and Foreign
item.description: The movie, starring Sophie Sloan and Mads Mikkelsen, is a blast of visual delights.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: 5 Children’s Movies to Stream Now
item.description: This month’s picks include an unexpected holiday adventure and a blockbuster body-swapping comedy.
item.dc:creator: Dina Gachman

item.title: ‘Silent Night, Deadly Night’ Review: A Slasher Gets a Giddy Reboot
item.description: This delightfully trashy entry in the seasonal subgenre follows a killer Santa with a heart, and a case of blood lust.
item.dc:creator: Beatrice Loayza

item.title: The Best Genre Movies of 2025
item.description: We look at the finest in science fiction, horror, action and international films, all available to stream.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli, Erik Piepenburg, Robert Daniels and Devika Girish
item.media:description: Aaron Taylor-Johnson, top, and Alfie Williams in a scene from "28 Years Later.”

item.title: Rob Reiner, Actor Who Went on to Direct Classic Films, Dies at 78
item.description: Mr. Reiner, who was in “All in the Family,” directed films including “This Is Spinal Tap,” “When Harry Met Sally …,” “The Princess Bride” and “A Few Good Men.”
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs
item.media:description: Rob Reiner in Los Angeles in 1986.

item.title: ‘Anna Christie’ Review: Michelle Williams on the Waterfront
item.description: The actress stars in Thomas Kail’s luminous revival of Eugene O’Neill’s play about a woman whose past threatens her future.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes
item.media:description: Michelle Williams in the 1921 drama “Anna Christie” at St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn.

item.title: James Cameron Tempers His Temper and Channels His Inner Na’vi
item.description: Years after his Titanic tantrums, the “Avatar” director has “mellowed,” says Sigourney Weaver. He calls it “marinating.”
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd
item.media:credit: JJ Geiger for The New York Times

item.title: Confirm or Deny: James Cameron Edition
item.description: The box office king sits for a lightning-round interview.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd
item.media:credit: JJ Geiger for The New York Times
item.media:description: He has an explanation for his “King of the World” statement.

item.title: Tom Hanks on the Electrifying (and Terrifying) Experience of Writing a Play
item.description: The actor also stars in the Off Broadway production of “This World of Tomorrow,” a yearslong project at the Shed through Dec. 21.
item.dc:creator: Tom Hanks and Thomas Prior
item.media:credit: Thomas Prior for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tom Hanks plays a tech entrepreneur from 2089 who travels back to the 1939 World’s Fair. He said he wanted to explore “lives caught between the certainties of our past and the unknowable future.”

item.title: Peter Greene, ‘Pulp Fiction’ and ‘The Mask’ Actor, Dies at 60
item.description: Mr. Greene, who built a four-decade career uncannily portraying villains, was found dead in his apartment in Manhattan on Friday, his manager said.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Desiree Navarro/Everett Collection, via Alamy Stock Photo
item.media:description: Peter Greene in New York in 2010. The New York Times once called his work “scarily authentic.”

item.title: 41 Things That Stuck With Us in 2025
item.description: Aunt Gladys. Tyler, the Creator. That sex scene in “The Naked Gun.” These are the things Culture staffers couldn’t stop thinking about this year.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: The Real Housewives of Orange County (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Neon; Sara Krulwich/The New York Times; Daniel Arnold, via Loose Joints; Warner Bros.

item.title: Stream These 10 Movies and TV Shows Before They Leave Netflix in January
item.description: A ton of titles are expiring soon for U.S. subscribers. Catch them while you can, including a Scorsese classic and one of TV’s most influential series.
item.dc:creator: Jason Bailey

item.title: Taylor Swift’s ‘The End of an Era’: 5 Takeaways
item.description: The six-part Disney+ series goes behind the scenes of the pop star’s record-breaking Eras Tour, revealing some of her creative processes and struggles.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman
item.category: The End of an Era (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Cassidy Araiza for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taylor Swift onstage at the opening night of the Eras Tour in March 2023.

item.title: Everyone Hates SantaCon. He Made a Movie About It.
item.description: Seth Porges shows the event in all its raucousness, but he is also sympathetic to its origins.
item.dc:creator: James Barron
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Wake Up Dead Man’ | Anatomy of a Scene
item.description: The writer and director Rian Johnson narrates a sequence from his film.
item.dc:creator: Mekado Murphy
item.category: Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery (Movie)
item.media:description: Josh O’Connor, left, and Daniel Craig in “Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery.”

item.title: ‘Afternoons of Solitude’ Looks for Beauty in the Bloodshed of Bullfighting
item.description: Albert Serra’s documentary “Afternoons of Solitude” seeks something transcendent in a tradition that many people, in Spain and elsewhere, find barbaric.
item.dc:creator: Carlos Aguilar
item.media:credit: Elliott Verdier for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Cinema brings you closer to life itself,” Albert Serra said.

item.title: ‘The King of Color’ Review: He’s Just Into Hue
item.description: In a new documentary, the creator of the Pantone system explains how he standardized colors across the globe.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: ‘Atropia’ Review: No Escape From Reality
item.description: Alia Shawkat and Callum Turner fake it so real in this Army simulation exercise in the California desert.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Kenny

item.title: Sundance 2026 Lineup Includes Charli XCX and Olivia Wilde
item.description: Olivia Wilde will also appear in two films, including one she directed, and the cast of “Little Miss Sunshine” will return for its 20th anniversary.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling
item.media:description: Charli XCX in “The Moment,” directed by Aidan Zamiri.

item.title: ‘Merv’ Review: Not Much to Gnaw On
item.description: Zooey Deschanel and Charlie Cox play a former couple who share a dog in this shaggy rom-com that fails its titular lead.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Kennedy

item.title: A.I. Actors Might Change Your View of Human Ones
item.description: Even the stars people think of as immaculately crafted Hollywood products look wildly, irreducibly human in comparison.
item.dc:creator: Jane Ackermann

item.title: Ryan Coogler on ‘Sinners,’ Chadwick Boseman and Why He Declined to Join the Academy
item.description: The director on what he’s thinking of post-“Sinners,” how the loss of Chadwick Boseman affected him and why he turned down the invitation to join the academy.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan
item.media:credit: Ariel Fisher for The New York Times
item.media:description: Coogler said he couldn’t engage with his work “as the kid whose dreams were to come to Hollywood and make movies. I have to engage with it as a professional shepherd of the story.”

item.title: When the Phone Number in That TV Show Actually Connects Somewhere
item.description: Passing on the classic 555 number, “Stranger Things” is the latest show to offer Easter eggs for viewers who try to call a fictional character.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather

item.title: ‘Marjorie Prime’ Review: A.I. Gave Her Back Her Husband. Was It Worth It?
item.description: June Squibb stars in the Broadway premiere of Jordan Harrison’s meditation on grief and the nature of human and artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli
item.media:description: June Squibb, right, plays the titular character of “Marjorie Prime,” with Christopher Lowell as an A.I. replica of her deceased husband as he was in his 30s.

item.title: Golden Globes 2026 Snubs and Surprises: ‘Wicked: For Good’ Misses a Major Nomination
item.description: Though its stars are up for acting prizes, the film is not in the running for best musical or comedy, only for box office achievement.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan

item.title: Golden Globe 2026 Nominees: Full List Including ‘One Battle After Another’
item.description: The movies and TV series competing for the 83rd Golden Globes. The ceremony will air on Jan. 11.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez
item.media:description: Leonardo DiCaprio, left, and Benicio Del Toro in “One Battle After Another,” nominated for nine Golden Globes.

item.title: Golden Globe Nominations Confirm the Allure of Warner Bros.
item.description: The studio’s film “One Battle After Another,” and an HBO show it owns, “The White Lotus,” scored the most nominations for movies and television shows.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling
item.category: Only Murders in the Building (TV Program)
